Dear Nicholas (as I remember your father calling you, when he mentioned you),

Your father, Kris (as he asked my wife and me to call him when he stayed at our home once, to deliver a lecture at The Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, was a kind, gentle man. He was a man of extreme modesty -- and a towering intellect in the academic field of political geography. His essay, "The Nature of Frontiers and Boundaries," for instance, is rightly considered a classic. That study, like his other writing, is an exposition of such lucidity and depth that it will always merit careful reading. I regularly have assigned it in my graduate seminar on Geography, Foreign Policy, and World Order, and, just recently, also to a special group of students -- fifteen young scholars, NGO staff members, and junior government officials from the Republic of Armenia! I am sure these young Armenians felt very proud when I told them that the essay's author was himself Armenian. (I had thought, years ago, that your father was initially Romanian -- until, as we were then driving through Watertown Square, he suddenly perked up. He was looking all around as we drove through the town, and then he told me a bit about his background -- and mentioned an Armenian-American newspaper published in Watertown that he regularly read.)

It was in the context of the Research Committee on Political and Cultural Geography (RC15) of the International Political Science Association (IPSA) that I, as well as many others, knew your father. My wife and I saw him last during the IPSA World Congress in Fukuoka, Japan. In his RC15 panel presentation in Fukuoka -- remarks whose effect I shall never forget -- he spoke movingly, earnestly, in a very personal way, inwardly almost, about his love of the forest, and a particular forested place. His political-geographic topic was the very specific region where he was born, and how, historically, it had changed hands. But I am sure he was thinking, too, of his new home in America -- in Oregon. A place that he helped to make with his own hands. With the help of yours, too.

It is an honor to have known your father. Thank you for writing about him, and for inviting the memories and reflections of others.

Alan, and Pam
I am so sorry for your loss.  I totally understand that your grief is in no way diminished by the fact that your father lived a long life.

Mr Kristoff: What a great column, and what a great father!
I lost my father in 1966. I, too, as a teenager, found myself embarassed at times. But like your dad, he was a really a great guy. He could fix anything- electrical, plumbing, carpentry,whatever. I learned a lot from him.

Mr. Kristof, your column resonated so closely, as I lost my father, also a beloved teacher and outdoorsman, on his birthday last month, and this is the first Father's Day without him too. It's taking a while to live into, and your beautiful tribute to your Dad reminds us that the celebration of a life well-lived abides alongside the grief of such loss. Writing helps, sharing the stories helps. Remembering helps. Even laughing helps. I hope my Dad greets your Dad in that great library in the forest. My Dad would love that. We say that he has 'hiked home to God'. What a difference, these men have made!
Peace to you and your family.

I am so sorry that you have lost your Dad - and he will always be with you. The most important part of him resides within you, your wife and your children and your many mutual friends. I know that you will feel your father's love for you for the rest of your life. And you will tell your children that even though you cannot be with them to the end of their lives, they will be loved by you, their father, every single day of their lives. And this will be true. And so it is for you too.

I lost my father last July and he was also 91 years old. I miss him every day. But I feel very lucky and very happy that I could really get to know my dad over so many years - well into my own "conscious" and adult life. My husband and children and I shared a lot of our lives with him and my mother, including your columns full of ideas and challenges. He often remarked about his many wonderful memories of people and of family he had known, loved, and of course, and at his age, sometimes lost. This has happened for you and your Dad would want you to think of your life with him and to enjoy the memories which you made together. You are a lucky man to have had such a good father who was also a wise, interesting, and loving friend. How lucky is that and how very wonderful?! Thank you for sharing him with all of us.

Mr Kristof,
My deepest condolences. My father, too was from Austria-Hungary, born in 1904, and gone since 1979. He was a Jew, and our family name is German because the Hapsburg Empire required all its citizens to have Germanic names, Who knows what it was before?

What a man your father was--the determination, courage, endurance that made his trip to America possible is positively heroic: no other word suffices. His brilliance, his worldview, his heart: my God, what a loss.

A few words of feeble comfort: Of course you look just like him. He must have taken joy in that, and without any doubt, he was immensely proud of the character and accomplishments of one fortunate enough to be his only son. Mr Kristof, you did right by your father.

Be at peace.

Your column about your father was a beautiful tribute to an extraordinary man. There's probably so much more that you could write about him. Have you considered the idea? His life would make a wonderful subject for a book.
Lillian Nordenholz

Nicholas,
That was such an honest article. Thank you for writing that and reminding us all that our fathers, regardless of their respective quirks, are one of the greatest treasures a man or woman can have. I myself am an immigrant. Although my father didn't escape the horrors that yours experienced, he clearly made a choice to leave a successful life for the future of his children. I am every obliged to him and I don't think I can ever find the words to thank him for what he has done. I come from a family where we are not necessarily open about our feelings. I just hope he knows how much he means to me.
RJT
Very moving, I did not have a father like that (tears)

Where to begin:
As far as the diving. Ultimately, it is the competitive nature of the players who feel winning at all costs, realizing the refs cannot see everything at all times, means exaggerating conduct.

This happens in every single sport: EVERY ONE! (Hockey: dives; Basketball: players hitting the deck to draw a charge; baseball: sweeping your mitt on the throw to 2nd base on a steal whether you tagged the guy or not/ catchers pulling the ball into the strike zone; Football: receivers holding the ball up on passes that obviously skip or hit the ground). It is an issue in all sports. So it has nothing to do with soccer or hating it, or this idea America sports are fair/untainted and better.

The problem with Soccer is that FIFA refuses to acknowledge and address the problem and so like petulant children the players push it and push it to new extremes. And now in a broadcast world of 30-40 cameras covering a match their bad behavior like a "bad" Nanny 911 episode(fostered by years of neglect) has become appalling.

Every major sport has found ways to combat their own unique "dives". Hockey, basketball: extra refs, video review for goals/end of period stuff; Baseball: more umps, clearly defined rolls for the umps (limited video review), Football: a brigade of refs/sideline officials, controlled video review, challenges, etc.

I think FIFA needs to emerge from 1962 and recognize what every other sport has: players today, and the game move much faster and with a greater alacrity than ever before. And the field is just as big. How is it that Hockey and Basketball on much smaller surfaces with half as many players to watch moving at higher speeds have twice as many officials?!

My suggestion would be to have it be similar to these sports: Add at least 1 or 2 full field refs. Return the side judges to only offsides (my observation is that these guys are hesitant to call anything major, and never go against the head ref and never call fouls more than 10 feet from the lines). have 3 officials on the sidelines to manage subs, the clock and the team coaching staff and benches and so forth. Finally, allow like in basketball for the officials to confer with each other over difficult calls.

Finally, as someone pointed out, allow for post-game video review to issue yellow cards for flagrant "dives". This will at least affect players status for future games and maybe put some "fear" in them.

All of these will not disrupt the continuity of the game, which is crucial, and a big part of hockey and basketball. (Hockey I think is very similar: the rules in hockey have basically 2 purposes: prevent injury and keep play moving fluidly (see: icing, delay of game, "clutching and grabbing" crackdown, diving))

No one expects perfect, but you we all can demand FIFA at least show up prepared. This World Cup has demonstrated they are not.
